titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:30. Thursday— Swam with Antoine and John 1. hour and 10 minutes— Intelligencer Manifesto— G. Sullivan here— Politics. Vice-Presidency. Entire uncertainty of the result— Jackson— Calhoun— Stackelberg presented him to P.U.S. to take leave— Salazar— Chassérieux going to Bogota— What will U.S. do. French recognition offered if Colombia will change her Government—and make a king— Say Bolivar— They will not— Salazar is to write— Watkins— The paragraph in the Intelligencer— Wrote an Answer. Short Evening walk.

2. VI.Watkins here and at the Office— At P.U.S. who sent for Calhoun. Read my draft of an Article, in answer to that of the Intelligencer. Discussed. Question whether any reference should be in it to the President— Statement that the negotiation of the Slave-trade Convention, was with the unanimous assent of the members of the Administration— Draft approved as written— J. P. Van Ness’s exclusion of N. Edwards from the celebration dinner— I proposed to withdraw my Subscription— Calhoun also J. M’Lean to be consulted—joint Letter to decline. Gave Watkins the draft of the Article— Tremendous thunder-gust— Walk after dinner with G. Sullivan—he came in— A. B. Woodward— His projected meeting for to-morrow Evening. Resolutions for abolition of Slavery— Advised him to countermand the Meeting, and talk with P.U.S. about the Resolutions— Note from P.U.S. with Mercer’s statement— Roused John from bed, and sent him to Force’s for the proof copy of the Article— He brought it, I made an alteration in it, and sent it back.

3. VI.Calhoun and M’Lean here— Draft of the joint Letter; declaring that we had withdrawn our subscriptions for the dinner— At P.U.S. submitted it to him, and he approved it— Call at Wirt’s Office— He agrees with us, joint Letter to T. Carbery and Jos. Gales jr. Copy prepared and published in the Washington Republican— Again at P.U.S. A. Scott with him—disapproves of the exclusion of N. Edwards.— Not to give notice to the foreign Ministers, that we have withdrawn our subscription— At the Office. Wyer: His agitation— Addington— About the rolled iron, and the South-Carolina Statute— Wants answers— Evening call at Frye’s. He not at home— Carbery late at my house— Answer from the Committee of Arrangements. His own excuses and apologies— Says the Committee of Arrangements, a Majority, were taken in. A member of the Committee had said that several persons had expressed objections to subscribe, or be present, if N. Edwards was to be there—and proposed that private notice should be given at the Bookstorer, not to receive Edwards’s subscription— No vote or Resolution of the Committee taken upon it—and Carbery himself inclined to object to it, but did not— He afterwards rather advised Van Ness not to give the direction, but he nevertheless did— It was not intended that it should be published, but Force did announce it. The
majority of the Committee were no supporters of the Candidate who is the antagonist of Mr Edwards— I told Carbery we were perfectly satisfied he had intended nothing improper— Article this morning in the National Journal.

4. VI—G. Sullivan— Wyer twice— Heard Little, Deuteronomy 26.5. and 1. Samuel 12.24. Independence Day Sermons— Wood, at Baker’s from Ecclesiastes 12.5— Man goeth to his long home— My Son John this day came of age— Gave him my note— Sent him to Mr Calhoun, with a reply to the answer from the Committee of Arrangements— Calhoun sent him back the reply signed by himself and Mclean— Wyer twice here— Writing this eve to Blunt.

5. V:30. Celebration of the Anniversary of Independence— Procession to the Capitol— At P.U.S. Went in the procession— Mr M’Lean with me. Prayer by Mr Hawley— General Philip Stuart read the Declaration of Independence. M. St. Clair Clarke, delivered a short Oration— Returned, without the procession to P.U.S. who received company— G. Sullivan’s doubts whether he would dine with me, or at Williamson’s— Concluded to dine with me, and did— Evening walk— Rockets— Cool weather.

6. VI.Wyer here. Accounts of the dinner at Williamson’s yesterday. About two thirds of the subscribers withdrew their names. Going to the Office, I met G. Hay, who spoke of certain expenses chargeable upon his agency before the Commissioners of Slave Claims— At the Office— Salazar, spoke of the dinner yesterday, as of small numbers and not agreeable. He is going to Philadelphia, and desired me to send my answer to his last Note there— Also a Copy of my Letter to R. C. Anderson upon the Colombian privateering Ordinance— N. Edwards, to enquire for a file of the Richmond Enquirer— Returned him the Letter from R. King and enclosures, that he had sent for the perusal of the President— A Mr Anderson called; and a man named James Sterrett, changed from that of Hare—who came for a pardon of his brother Lewis Hare, a Mail Robber. He is to have it to morrow. Copies of Answer from Committee of Arrangements, and reply, sent for the National Journal and Washington Republican.

7. V:30. Morning rain—cleared off— Correspondence with the Committee of arrangements, in the National Journal— Writing a statement of facts relating to the debate on the Embargo— Note from P.U.S. Cabinet Meeting at Noon. Only Calhoun and myself present— Salazar’s Note— How to be answered— The Colombian Republic to maintain its own Independence— Hope that France and the Holy Allies, will not resort to force against it— If they should the power to determine our resistance is in Congress— The movements of the Executive will be as heretofore expressed— I am to draft an Answer.
State of Mr Crawford’s health. Attorney General’s opinion, use of a facsimile lawful—conditionally, if the mind and sight are competent to the transaction of business— Otherwise P.U.S. ought to make a temporary appointment— Calhoun differed from Wirt’s opinion— Thought the practice eminently dangerous— Case of Governor M’Kean in Pennsylvania— Papers relating to it sent by N. Biddle to Crawford— P.U.S. will refer to the Comptroller Anderson, to see Mr Crawford; ascertain his own opinion, and report— Evening walk to N. Frye’s— I was writing a statement of facts relating to the Embargo debate.

8. V: Swam with John in the Potowmack. 1 hour 20 minutes— B. O. Tyler was here with engraved Portraits of W. H. Crawford and A. Jackson— Wishes me to sit to Wood— Washington, National Intelligencer second Manifesto, two columns against the Secretary of State— Watkins here— Advice to him, regarding the National Journal— G. Sullivan— Controversies of Edwards and Crawford. P.U.S. sent for me— Met Calhoun there— Mrs Monroe taken ill last night so that the President could not go to Loudoun as he had intended— Mr Crawford sent him word by Mr Anderson that he would call on him this day, but he did not. I asked if there had not been several Treasury warrants paid, without any signature of the Secretary— P.U.S. did not know— At the Office, Smylie, a Clergyman, brought a Letter of Introduction— W. Archer, and Franklin Insurance Company Stock. At the new Branch Bank— Letter from Mrs Adams asking for the Carriage to be sent for her— G. Sullivan dined with us. The weather intensely warm— Comment upon the Article in the Intelligencer.

9. V:15. Swam with John and Antoine. 1 1/2 hour— Fahrenheit 92—and the heat insupportable. J. M’Lean called, and read me an Article, prepared, upon the subject of our declining to attend the dinner— Watkins was here; and afterwards at the Office— I gave him the Article in reply to the National Intelligencer, and D. Brent’s statement— Call at the Franklin Insurance Company Office, and settled the transaction with W. Archer— At the Office— John Mitchell came about the settlement of some old Accounts of his as Consul at Martenico. Waters Smith for settlement of Accounts at St. Augustine in Florida— He brought a Letter from the U.S. judge Jos. L. Smith. I referred him to the Treasury Department— B. S. Watts came to be despatched, as Secretary of Legation to Colombia—but I was not ready for him. He spoke of an outfit—and intimated one or two cases in which he understood it had been allowed to Secretaries of Legation— Purviance one— Wyer dined with us—

10. V:30.John went off between 4 and 5. this morning with the Carriage; for his mother. Swam in the Potowmack 1 1/2 hour with Antoine— D. Brent came with a subscription paper for a dinner to T. Law next Monday, to which I subscribed. Baron Stackelberg came to say he expected to embark next Wednesday from Alexandria for Bremen— P. Hagner to enquire if
Captain Randall could not be recalled from his Mission to the Havana; where he has had the yellow fever— G. Sullivan evening ride and walk with him— Call from Mr Allen, the Clergyman of Baltimore. His patent inventions, and the proposition to him to accept a professorship in the University of Ohio, at a Salary of 800 dollars. a year— At the President’s with Letters from the Slave-indemnity Commissioners— Draft of answer to them— Mr Crawford’s health and fac simile— Anderson’s report— Speaks strongly of Mr Crawford’s rapid convalescence; refers the main question to the President’s own observation upon an interview promised by Mr Crawford, on the 8th. but he did not come— Many warrants were paid without any signature by Mr Crawford— But after payment the fac simile was applied to them. P.U.S. said he would call upon Anderson, for a more specific report— Wyer dined with me— Evening calls from Mr Pleasonton, and his Son, a Cadet at West-Point, on furlough. G. Hay, who came to say that Seawell complained I delayed the proceedings of the Commissioners by not answering their Letters— I said I had the answer written; but did not know why they wrote me Letters.

11. V:30. My birth-day. 57. Swam in the Potowmac—clad; about three quarters of an hour. Heard Mr Little from 1. Peter 1.7.8. [“]That the trial of your faith, being much more precious than of gold, that perisheth, though it be tried with fire, might be found unto praise and honor and glory at the appearing of Jesus Christ:—Whom having not seen ye love: in whom though now ye see him not, yet believing, ye rejoice with joy unspeakable and full of glory.”— After the service the communion was administered, and Mr Little gave notice there would be no Evening worship. In the afternoon I heard Mr Baker from Ephesians 5.16. “Redeeming the time.”— G. Sullivan and Wyer dined with me—and in the Evening Wyer walked with me to Mr Frye’s— My occupations are much disturbed.

12. V:30. Rainy Morning. Dr. Thornton called, and said he had written some remarks upon Governor Troup of Georgia’s Letter about the Cherokee Indians—whom he was for extirpating— And he judged Mr Crawford was of that opinion, because Mr S. H. Smith his neighbor was so, and he thought of publishing these remarks— I told him I had no reason to believe Mr Crawford was of Governor Troup’s opinion on the subject; and I should advise him not to publish any remarks of that import.— Williamson’s barkeeper came for my subscription to the dinner on the 5th. which I paid. Received a Note from P.U.S. for a Cabinet Meeting at one— Calhoun and Southard there. Letters from Genl. La Fayette and James Brown. Discussions about the expenses of La Fayette’s visit to this Country. Best to do nothing upon it now. Brown mentions a Letter from H. Middleton of 2 May saying
he had concluded a satisfactory Convention, on the North-west Coast question— Blessed be God, if true— Ferreira, a Portuguese Brazilian, came with a Letter from Judge Story. He wished to see P.U.S. Stackelberg came and introduced Lorich as Swedish Chargé d’Affaires in his absence. Walked with Calhoun to Queen’s Hotel, Capitol Hill, to a subscription dinner given to T. Law, upon his projected return to England— About 100 persons. Walk with Calhoun near to Georgetown— Called and sat an hour with G. Sullivan— Rain home late.

13. V. Sleepless night— Watkins here— Gave him third Article in reply to the National Intelligencer— Force, Editor of the National Journal has purchased the Establishment of the Washington Republican, and commences a paper thrice a week, to be made hereafter if possible a daily paper. Mr Thomas Law came and took leave. Going to-morrow to embark for England. At the President’s twice; and introduced to him Mr Lorich, Consul General of Sweden, as Charge d’Affaires in the absence of Baron Stackelberg. Lorich made a short speech, but in so low a tone of voice that I could not hear him. The President sent for Mr Pleasonton, and directed him to the settlement of Wyer’s accounts— The Count de Menou came, to the Office, and said he had expected, the arrival of the Minister Durant de Mareuil, this day; but that he probably would not now come till next Tuesday. He spoke too of the certificates of origin from French Consuls, required at the Customs-houses in France— W. Lee, inquired about Baron Maltitz’s character. He is addressing one of Lee’s daughters— A. M. Jackson came with a renewed application, for an appointment as Clerk in the Department of State. Wyer dined with me— Evening rain. Letter from A. Hamilton.

14. VI. Coll.B. Loring brought me a Letter from P. Sharpe; a son of whom was with him— I called at G. Graham’s—Commissioner of the Land-Office, with two Letters of A. Hamilton, concerning the Land-Archives in Florida—difficulties of acting on the subject— To see W. G. D. Worthington. At the Office— Mr Lorich called to take leave— Going to morrow, for Philadelphia. G. Sullivan— J. M’Lean the Postmaster General— Spoke of the National Intelligencer— Third Article in reply—in this Morning’s National Journal— Post-Office Advertisements refused to the City Gazette. Sullivan and Wyer dined with me, and were here again successively in the Evening— Sullivan goes for Boston, to-morrow Morning.

15. V:30.Mr S. L. Southard, Secretary of the Navy called upon me, and we had a long conversation upon various topics of public interest. He told me of the movements of his old Colleague, M. Dickerson, since his return to New-Jersey; and he thinks the only key to Dickerson’s thoughts and actions is personal hostility to him— The Jealousy of a younger man, rising and supplanting him in political influence, power and reputation.
Southard spoke of despatching the Hornet from Norfolk; with Watts and Mann— At the Office— Watkins, relating to the Florida-claim commission. Copies of papers desired— At the President’s— He goes to Loudoun to-morrow— Dined alone— Baron Stackelberg came and took leave— Frye called here— Walk with him— Visit at Southard’s. Mrs Southard has now come with him— On returning home I found Dr. S. Moore— He had called at the Office before dinner— He had a Letter from W. Jones of Philadelphia, enclosing an unsigned paper from Mr Patterson, the director of the Mint, tendering his resignation, and urging the appointment of Dr. Moore, his Son-in-Law, in his place— The President had referred Dr Moore this morning to Mr Crawford, who was at his house in the City— This Evening he had brought an endorsement by the President upon W. Jones’s Letter, directing a Commission to Dr Moore be made out. He wanted it immediately— I sent for R. Forrest, who went to the Office of the Department and made out and brought a Commission, which I signed and delivered to Dr Moore.

16. VI. Morning at home without interruption. The President went to Loudoun— At the Office— Commodore Chauncy— Two brothers Allen, sons of the Clergyman of Baltimore— Waters Smith Marshal of East-Florida: who spoke of the great earnestness of the people there, to have their Land-titles decided upon— Watkins, who sent me two Letters from Maryland. Letter to Alexander Hamilton— Instructions to Mann for Guatemala— Dined alone— Evening walk with Wyer to Commodore Porter’s— Mrs Porter’s Shells— Miss Watson there, and others.

17. V:30.Wyer here. Fourth Article in the National Intelligencer. Wrote a short and closing answer to it. At the Office. B. S. Watts came to take leave; going to-morrow for Norfolk; the Instructions to T. Mann were given him.— Slacum, the Consul appointed for Buenos-Ayres came to say he was going to Boston—to return here about the first of September, shortly afterwards to embark— Dined at Commodore Chauncey’s, with Messrs.Calhoun and Southard, and Commodore Morris— Mrs Chauncy, and Miss Ann M’Knight were at table— Chauncey has been appointed to the command of the Navy-Yard at New-York, and is shortly to remove thither. We sat at table, till after dark— On returning home, I found a Note from A. H. Everett who is at Brown’s Hotel— Dr. Watkins and his Son were afterwards here.

18. VI. Called at Brown’s Hotel, and invited Mr Everett to my house. He came home with me; and we heard in the forenoon Mr Baker, from Luke 14.23. [“]And the Lord said unto the Servant, Go out into the highways
and hedges, and compel them to come in, that my house may be filled.” Between the services Dr. Huntt called in— In the afternoon, I heard Mr Baker again from Hebrews 7.25. “Wherefore he is able also to save them to the uttermost that come unto God by him, seeing he ever liveth to make intercession for them”— E. Wyer dined with us, and I had long evening visits from Dr Thornton & Dr Watkins.

19. VI.Dr Thornton called; and Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General; who mentioned that he had a Letter from Mr Eleazar Early at Providence, where there has been a recent politic convocation. B. O. Tyler came with a request that I would sit to Mr Wood, the miniature painter; for a small engraving that he proposes to have made— I went and sat, about a quarter of an hour— As I returned a Mr Smith of Georgetown came to solicit employment in the Department. Very urgent— I went with Mr Everett, and introduced him to Mr Calhoun and Mr Southard, at their Offices. Mr W. C. Somerville called at the Office, with a paper relating to a claim for a lost Slave, before the Commissioners— He had sent me this Morning a Letter, with an electioneering Address which he proposes to deliver at a meeting in Virginia— I had not had time to read it; but promised to return it to him this Evening or to-morrow morning— Mr Pleasonton called with a Mr Clark who renewed an application for the appointment of Consul at Altena— But as I objected that this would interfere with the Consulate at Hamburg, he said he would accept of the appointment as Consul at Lubeck— Mr James Lanman came to inquire if it would be safe for him to go out with his Commission, as Consul at Jamaica— I could not tell him— But advised him to wait with Patience, in the belief that it would ultimately prove a profitable place.— Mr George Hay called at my house after dinner, and promised to call at my Office to-morrow— Mrs Adams returned this Evening, with Mary Hellen, and John, from Bedford. They came in a Hack; one of our horses having been foundered, on the way thither, and the Carriage and Coachman being left at Middletown.

20. VI. I called on Mr Somerville at Williamson’s Hotel, and returned to him his manuscript address— He left the City at Noon, for Fredericksburg— I had a long conversation with him, and then gave a sitting of a half an hour to Wood— Mr L. Rice called at my house, and still postpones a settlement. A man by the name of Gregory came to the Office, apparently a German Jew, but last from England; insane, and imploring protection from a universal conspiracy to poison him. Mr Hay came as he had promised and seemed much excited, at what he thinks a system of delusion, with regard to the state of Mr Crawford’s health— He appeared
to suppose it important that its real condition, ought to be made known by newspaper discussion— But I observed that all the authentic and responsible information shewed that he was almost well— That mere fact against authenticated proof would easily be discredited— That time must soon shew, whether Mr Crawford is or is not getting well, and that little could be effected by argument in anticipation of Events. We had much more Conversation upon this and other subjects— The Count de Menou came to tell me that he was again disappointed in the expectation of the arrival of the Minister, Durant de Mareuil. Mr Rind once Editor of the Washington Federalist, late a Clerk in the Bank of Columbia came, to solicit employment in the Department— I was informed that Mr Man who was going out as agent to Guatemala, died last Saturday or Sunday at Norfolk— Wyer called at the Office. Walk after dinner with Mrs Adams and Everett. Last Article in the National Journal, in reply to the Intelligencer— Commodore Chauncey and Dr Thornton were here this Evening— Letter to N. F. Williams and enclosure.

21. V: Swam in the Potowmack, with Mr Everett, John and Antoine. Mr D. Brent called this morning, to mention the confirmation of the report of the death of Mr Man, on board the Peacock, at Norfolk— I gave a third sitting to Wood the painter—about half an hour— He now proposes an interval— At the Office Captain Jackson, Commander of the late Revenue Cutter, came to complain that he had been discharged from the service, without any complaint against him; merely because his vessel has been condemned, as no longer Seaworthy. His Lieutenant is in the same situation. He said Jones the chief Clerk of the Treasury had done it of his own authority; and Dickins told him, Mr Crawford knew nothing of it— I called upon the Comptroller, Anderson, who said he would speak of it to the Secretary of the Treasury— He thought the Officers could not be discharged, merely because the vessel was condemned, and that another Cutter ought to be stationed upon the Coast of Louisiana— He told me that Mr Crawford was very much better since he removed into the Country; and that he believed he never would have recovered at the house where he had resided in the City. Mr Southard called to enquire whether in consequence of the death of Mr Man, it would be necessary to detain the Hornet— No. Dr Watkins was at the Office— Mr Frye called in the Evening, and I walked with him to Gadsby’s Hotel, and subscribed for the dinner to be given to-morrow, to Commodore Rodgers. After I came home A. B. Woodward was here; applying for the appointment vacated by the death of T. N. Man.

22. V. Swam an hour and twenty minutes with John. After Breakfast Mr A. B. Woodward came in—repeating his application for the appointment to Guatemala; and conversing largely upon other subjects— Some papers of his entitled Considerations upon the Presidency addressed to the individual Citizen are being published in the National Journal— They are speculative and historical; referring to past Events, but bearing so much upon those of the present time, that I told him he was treading close upon warm ashes. Mr G. Hay called to visit Mr Everett; but he was out, and Mr Hay conversed with me— He told me that Gales of the Intelligencer had been to the President, who had with great severity reproached him for the treacherous manner in which the Newspaper has for a long time been managed— The President had not mentioned this to me, but Gales told Mr Everett yesterday, that he had been to the President, and was sorry to find him entertaining precisely the same impressions that I did— Mr John Thomas the Architect came to request that I would speak to Mr Calhoun about his projects of improvements; and mentioned his wish to enter for the premium proposed by the Secretary of War, for the best mode of removing Snags, Sawyers and Planters from the bed of the Mississippi— At the Office, J. M’Lean the Postmaster General called. I attended the dinner at Gadsby’s, given to Commodore Rodgers— There were near a hundred persons, but they were divided between two tables, in different rooms. Mr T. Munro the Postmaster was the Chairman. I came away early after dinner. We spent the Evening at Dr Thornton’s. Dr Watkins came in at the close of the Evening from the dinner.

23. VI:30. Swam with John and Antoine, an hour and 35 minutes. Mr Everett went with Dr Sewall to Mount-Vernon. At the Office. Captain Jackson of the revenue Cutter came, and told me that Mr Dickins had informed him, that he was not removed; and that Mr Crawford proposed to build another Cutter— He applied also again for payment of 300 dollars paid by him to a lawyer as Counsel for him at Pensacola, on the trial of a vessel carried in by him at a time when there was no District Attorney at Pensacola. There is question whether it can be put on public account. Young Bourne, late Captain of the Marine Corps came again to solicit influence to obtain his restoration. The President and Secretary of the Navy had determined to restore him; but by a new act of indiscretion he has again forfeited their favorable disposition— I told him I would do what I could for him; but that it was impossible long to befriend a man who was his own enemy— I wrote to L. Cheves and began a letter to Mr Salazar— Evening with Mrs Adams— Miss Ann M’Knight came to pass some days with Mary Hellen.

24. V:30. Rainy morning. Letter from A. Hamilton, enclosing one from me to Baron Steuben, dated 17. Jany 1794— Call with Everett at Mr Wirt’s Office, and introduced him— Wyer at my Office. Dined at Mr Calhoun’s at Georgetown— Rodgers, Chauncey and Morris— Clark of Missouri, Southard, Rebello and a Mr Brisbane were there. Mrs Calhoun dined at table, and her mother appeared at Coffee. Everett went with me, and we walked home— Found Mrs Talbot here.

25. V:45. Swam with John and Antoine 1. hour and a quarter. I attended with Mr Everett at Mr Little’s, and heard him from Philippians 2.12.16 “Work out your own salvation with fear and trembling— For it is God which worketh in you both to will and to do of his good pleasure”— The Lecture was omitted; but, he gave notice that he would at some convenient time dedicate to the service of God the children of the Society, whose Parents might desire it. But he should not baptize them; believing that such ceremony was not warranted by Scripture— The other was a convenience for keeping a register of births, in the Society— In the afternoon I heard from Mr Baker, a Lecture upon Jacob’s Dream. Genesis 28.10–22— Immediately after dinner, Mr Lucius Bull came as a special Messenger from Mr Middleton at St. Petersburg with despatches, including a Convention concerning the North-west Coast question, signed 7/19 April— Baron Tuyll paid us an Evening visit—and I took a short walk with Mrs Adams. So that I lost the evening service at Mr Little’s.

26. V:30. Intermitted the morning bath; owing to a slight indisposition. Mr M’Lean the Postmaster-General called this morning— Going to-morrow upon his excursion to Saratoga— Visit from Mr Clark of Missouri— Call from Mr Fenwick of the Georgetown College, to invite me to the exhibition there on Wednesday. A Mr Davis from Connecticut came with many certificates of character to apply for the employment in the Department of State— A. B. Woodward, to repeat his application for the appointment of agent to Guatemala. At the Office. Captain Jackson of the Revenue Cutter Louisiana renewed his application for payment of a lawyer’s account against him, upon the trial of a vessel taken by him. Mr Brent was not at the Office, and I desired him to call to-morrow. Wyer paid his usual visit— Received a Letter from my son George; and one from E. Clough— Finished draught of a Note to Salazar. Walk with Everett after dinner— The day was intensely warm and remembered as the anniversary of my Marriage— Twenty-seven years have since elapsed.

27. V: Swam in the Potowmack an hour and ten minutes with John— The day was intensely hot. At the Office; Captain Jackson of the Revenue Cutter Louisiana, came again for the Settlement of his Account; for which he was referred to the Treasury Department— He said he had been this morning to see Mr Crawford, at his house in the Country; and he had told him that unless the President should direct that another Cutter should be employed on my Coast of Louisiana, he must consider himself as discharged from the service— I wrote several Letters respecting the land title Archives at St. Augustine— Left the last unfinished. Wyer at the Office— We had company to dine— Messrs.Calhoun, Chauncey, Clark of Missouri, Coll. Gibson, G. Graham, G. Hay, C. Hay, Genl.Jesup, Come: Morris, Coll. Roberdeau, Come. Rodgers, Southard, Watkins and Wirt— The Dinner was as pleasant as the heat of the weather would admit— Brutus in the City Gazette.

28. V:15. Swam with John and Antoine, an hour and ten minutes in the Potowmack; to the Bridge against the tide— Wrote a Statement of the transaction concerning Mrs Moulton’s Note— At the Office— Wyer— His Conversation this morning with Anthony— L. Bull the bearer of despatches from Mr Middleton came for the settlement of his Account— To be paid to-morrow. A. B. Nones to make application for the appointment of Consul at Maracaybo. He left several Letters of recommendation, and is to produce others. I dined with Mr Everett and my son John at Baron Tuyll, the Russian Minister’s. Conversations with him, and with Mr Addington— Wyer here in the Evening— Attack upon him in the City Gazette.

29. V. Swam with John and Antoine, an hour and 12 minutes, to and from the Potowmack bridge— Tide coming in, the approach to the Bridge was difficult— At the Office, Mr G. Hay called, and told me the President would come to the City this day— Mr W. G. D. Worthington recently appointed a Commissioner of Land-titles at St. Augustine came and I had a long conversation with him, upon the Instructions to be given to the Commissioners, under a Resolution of the House of Representatives at the late Session of Congress. I told him I thought the Instruction must be in general terms, and would be little more than a caution to guard against frauds and impositions upon the public— I desired him to read the Reports of the former Commissioners and to see me again. Mr Addington called to make enquiries concerning the late extraordinary transactions in Portugal— I read him the accounts of them given in General Dearborn’s despatches— Commodore Rodgers called upon me with E. Wyer— I went out after dinner with Mr Everett, and paid a visit to Mr Crawford, at his residence in the Country— We found him convalescent, in cheerful Spirits, and intending to go next week upon his excursion to Pennsylvania and New-York. His articulation still affected by a Salivation not entirely passed off; but he appears otherwise quite well—

30. V:15. Swam with John and Antoine, to and from the Bridge— I was an hour and a quarter, going, and a quarter of an hour returning. The tide ran so strong that I could barely stem it; and I increased the difficulty by crossing the channel— At the Office, Mr Worthington came, and intimated a disinclination to accept the appointment of Commissioner of Land titles, at St. Augustine: hinted at the danger of going there, at this Season—and at the impossibility of doing justice to the Country without incurring unpopularity among the people there. He expressed a wish for the appointment of Agent to Guatemala— Mr Joseph Forrest came to shew the necessity that he should continue his attendance at the Office, to furnish transcripts for claimants of awards under the Florida Treaty— Mr Rebello, the Brazilian Charge d’Affaires called to say he was going next week upon an excursion of a few days to Baltimore— W. T. Bourne brought several Letters and certificates of good conduct, to enforce his petition to be restored as a Captain in the Marine Corps— I dined with Mr Everett at Mr Southard’s— The Navy Commissioners, Genl. Clark of Missouri, G. Graham, G. Hay and T. Watkins were there. Mrs Southard at table, and her daughter— Southard gave me to read, a Letter to him from C. W. Gooch, one of the Editors of the Richmond Enquirer— The President arrived this evening from Loudoun.

31. V. We had intended to make a party this day, to the great Falls of the Potowmac; but the arrival of the President last Evening in the City; and the great heat of the day induced a postponement of it— Dr Watkins called here after breakfast.— I read to him the paper I had written containing the statement of facts, relating to Mrs Moulton’s note— But I concluded not to publish it for the present. General Daniel Parker came to take leave: He spoke of a claim that he has, as a Creditor upon a sum granted by an Act of Congress to the Representatives of J. H. Piatt; and of his apprehension that Mr Calhoun would use influence to prevent his obtaining it— Mr. John Thomas the naval Architect came to offer again to the Government his services in the line of his profession. He is desirous of being employed at Boston, because Commodore Bainbridge is at the Navy Yard there. At eleven O’Clock I went with Mr Everett to the Presidents; who half an hour afterwards received the deputations of Indians, who have recently arrived in the City— They are of six tribes, among the most savage of the desert part of them all but naked— They were Saukeys or Sturgeon’s, Musqukeys or Foxes, Piankashaws or Miamias, Pah-a-geser Ioways the people seen in a fog—Menomine or Wild Oats, Chippeways, and Nacatas or Sioux’s, the amiable people— They speak five different
languages and the discourse between the President and them was rendered by as many interpreters— For the Sauks and Foxes there was a double interpretation, first into French and thence into English— The President made a very short speech of welcome to them which was answered with like brevity, by a principal chief of each tribe— There were among them three Squaws and one female child five or six years old— In the speeches of the chiefs there was much gravity, and painful earnestness— They were mostly painted red; but one chief had his whole face coloured with yellow Ochre— Mrs Southard and Mrs Wirt, with their daughters, Old Mrs Calhoun, were there as Spectators, and many others. C. B. King the Painter among the rest— Messrs. Calhoun, Southard and Wirt were present as members of the Administration. And attended after the Indians were dismissed a Cabinet Meeting At which the Convention signed by Mr Middleton on the 17th. of April, and others of his despatches were read— The President was well satisfied with the Convention, and expressed his full approbation of the conduct of Mr Middleton in the Negotiation of it. But it is to be passed upon by the Senate at their next Session, and will have to encounter the same Spirit, which was at work against the Slave-trade Convention— The confidential despatch respecting the Affairs of South-America, and of Greece was likewise read— Few remarks upon it were made. The President said he would read over the other papers, and confer with me concerning them next week— The heat of this day was so oppressive that from dinner time I passed the Evening in idleness.

Day. I rise between five and six; and when the tide serves swim between one and two hours in the Potowmack— Breakfast about nine, then write or meditate, or receive visitors till one or two. Attend at my Office till six, then home to dine— Take an evening walk of half an hour, and from ten to eleven retire to bed— There are eight or ten Newspapers of extensive circulation published in various parts of the Union, acting in close concert with each other, and pouring forth continual streams of Slander upon my character and reputation, public and private— No falsehood is too broad, and no insinuation too base for them; and a great portion of their calumnies, are of a nature, that no person could shew or even assert their falsehood but myself— As the Presidential Election approaches, numerous Correspondents from every quarter, write me Letters professing good will, or enquiring of my opinions, from men, most of them entirely unknown to me; I answer very few; and perhaps ought to answer none of them— Particular friends write to me, by way of consultation, and of anxiety; and they can seldom be answered with entire Freedom. The result is a great waste of time, and of mental occupation upon subjects personal to myself, to the necessary neglect of public business, and detriment to the
public service— I have no reason to hope to be released from this state of trial, for many months to come— To pass through it with a pure heart, and a firm Spirit, is my duty and my prayer.
